FacilityName: Rinchem Company LLC. - Savannah Export CSC 40

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0 Executive Summary
Rinchem Company, LLC certifies to the best of the signer's knowledge, information, and belief formed after reasonable inquiry, the information submitted is true, accurate, and complete.

1.1. The Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Rinchem Company LLC., Garden City (Savannah), GA Facility.
Rinchem Company, LLC. (Rinchem) is committed to being a responsible member of the community in which it operates by giving top priority to operating in a safe and environmentally sound manner. Policy dictates that Rinchem personnel continuously identify methods to reduce the risk of handling hazardous materials and to reduce the risk to the community and environment through implementation of new technology and procedures. This commitment to safe and environmentally sound operations is documented in the Team Member Handbook, and the mission statement, which are available to all employees.
The Safety and Health policy states: SAFETY FIRST is more than a slogan at Rinchem...it is a way of life. 
Rinchem is committed to providing a safe working environment for its staff members, its customers and the public, and maintains that "NO JOB IS MORE IMPORTANT THAN THE HEALTH AND SAFETY OF OUR STAFF MEMBERS, OUR COMMUNITIES, AND THE ENVIRONMENT". We recognize that the responsibilities for safety and health are shared:
Management, in particular the Director of Quality, ES&H, accepts the responsibility for leadership of the safety and health program, for its effectiveness and improvement, and for providing the safeguards required to ensure safe conditions. Managers and supervisors are responsible for ensuring processes are documented which reinforce safety as well as the use
of engineering controls as the preferred method of promoting safety and eliminating unsafe conditions. Staff members are responsible for cooperation with all aspects of the safety and health program including compliance with all rules, documented procedures, and regulat

ions and for continuously practicing safety while performing their duties. Staff members are
responsible for stopping activities that may lead to injuries to themselves or others. Staff members, being the most familiar with actual operations, are responsible to document suggestions for continual improvements. Each employee is granted the authority to stop work if it is deemed unsafe. The job will not be continued until the work methods are evaluated and changed, if necessary, to make the work area safe. Management continues to do all it can to protect the Health and Safety of all staff and to provide a safe working environment. However, safety requires the participation of everyone...only you can make safety a reality. Be alert for conditions which appear unsafe. Report unsafe conditions immediately. Report any accident, "near miss", exposure, incident, spill or release.

1.2. A Description of the Savannah, GA Facility and Regulated Substances Handled.
The Savannah, GA facility is located at 5565 Export Blvd., Garden City, GA 31408. The facility provides transportation and public warehousing services for manufacturers, distributors and end users of prepackaged specialty chemicals. Warehousing activities include shipping, receiving, and storage of chemicals as specified by customer requirements. Toxic and flammable regulated substances are stored at the Savannah, GA warehouse which include the RMP regulated substances boron trifluoride, dichlorosilane, hydrogen chloride (anhydrous), epichlorohydrin, ethylenediamine, and vinyl acetate monomer.
Rinchem receives  boron trifluoride, dichlorosilane, hydrogen chloride (anhydrous), epichlorohydrin, ethylenediamine, and vinyl acetate monomer by truck as shipped from the manufacturer or distributor. It is unloaded from the truck using a forklift and staged for inspection. After the product passes an initial quality and safety inspection, it is received and tracked in an electronic inventory management system. The hazard class

ification of each product is programmed into inventory management system which directs the product to be placed into the hazard-specific storage location until it is shipped to the end user.  
After an order is received, the product is picked and staged for a pre-shipment quality and safety inspection. After the material passes inspection, it is loaded on to a truck using a forklift for shipment the end user .  

1.3. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention 
Rinchem management realizes that implementation of appropriate administrative and technological safeguards ensure the safety of the workers and the continued safety of public receptors. Those recommendations that are planned for implementation will be discussed in
"Planned Changes to Improve Safety". The safeguards taken include both administrative and technological safeguards that prevent, detect, or mitigate releases of boron trifluoride, dichlorosilane, hydrogen chloride (anhydrous), epichlorohydrin, ethylenediamine, or vinyl acetate monomer.

1.4. The Five Year Accident History
There has never been a reportable accident involving boron trifluoride, dichlorosilane, hydrogen chloride (anhydrous), epichlorohydrin, ethylenediamine, and vinyl acetate monomer or any other chemical at the Rinchem Company LLC, Savannah, GA warehouse.

1.5. The Emergency Response Program
Overall safety at the Rinchem Company, LLC, Savannah, GA warehouse is governed not only by our ability to prevent accidental releases of boron trifluoride, dichlorosilane, hydrogen chloride (anhydrous), epichlorohydrin, ethylenediamine, or vinyl acetate monomer from occurring, but also by the ability to mitigate any accidental releases of the above mentioned material. The Rinchem Company, LLC, Savannah, GA warehouse is a non-responding facility and utilizes contracted third-party services for spill response and cleanup. Rinchem employees may respond to releases of these chemicals by containing the spill when

it can be done safely. The Savannah warehouse Emergency Action Program consists of a Business Continuity Plan and facility specific Emergency Action Plan. The Emergency Action Program outlines the instructions and required information in order to notify emergency responders to fire, chemical spills, natural disasters, and other emergencies that may arise. The Emergency Action Plan and related notification documents are reviewed at least annually and revised as necessary to reflect changes that may occur to content and structure of the plan.
Notification exercises:
In response to the requirements set forth in 40 CFR 68.96(a), Rinchem has developed procedures to conduct an exercise of the stationary source's emergency response notification mechanisms. As all Rinchem Company, LLC facilities are non-responding stationary sources, Rinchem management and EHS recognize the importance of communication to emergency
response organizations of the hazards that are present at Rinchem facilities. Rinchem has, and will continue to send community outreach letters to emergency response organizations (LEPC, Fire and Police) and invite these organizations to tour our stationary sources and participate in accidental release drills.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety
The facility evaluates, resolves, and implements employee suggestions and recommendations resulting from routine hazard reviews, audits, process hazard analyses, and incident
investigations. Changes may be made to improve safety based on comments and information developed within our organization and the industry. Rinchem is always looking at ways to minimize risk through process improvement, upgrades to equipment used in the process, and review of operating procedures. Rinchem believes that no changes are necessary at this time to address improvement to safety at our facilities. Rinchem's procedures, safety policies, facility design, and many other preventative measures are adequate to keep its employees, the community
and the environment safe. Rinchem remains committed to continued  improvments to our safe work and corrective action processes to ensure the safe performance of all operations.
